name: Representation Theory
author: James and Liebeck
preface: This book is a demonstration of the Tarskido system, and is not intended for distribution.

62754a34-9254-4981-98dc-c4f05e849c60.name: Maschke's Theorem
62754a34-9254-4981-98dc-c4f05e849c60.statement:
Let $G$ be a finite group, let $F$ be $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{C}$, and let $V$ be an $FG$-module. If $U$ is an $FG$-submodule of $V$, then there is an $FG$-submodule $W$ of $V$ such that

$$ V = U \oplus W$$

8fe5ca1a-10dd-4e68-9f54-e47888a355dc.statement:
Suppose that $\pi$ is a projection of a vector space $V$. Then 

$$ V = \text{Im } \pi \oplus \text{Ker }\pi $$

proof_lines.statement:
If $v \in V$ then $v = v\pi + (v - v\pi)$. This first term $v\pi$ belongs to $\text{Im }\pi$, and the second term $v - v\pi$ lies in $\text{Ker } \pi$, since

$$(v - v\pi)\pi = v\pi - v\pi^2 = v\pi - v\pi = 0.$$

This establishes that $V = \text{Im }\pi + \text{Ker }\pi$. Now suppose that $v$ lies in $\text{Im }\pi \cap \text{Ker }\pi$. As $v \in \text{Im } \pi$, we have $v = u\pi$ for some $u \in V$. Therefore

$$ v \pi = u \pi^2 = u \pi = v.$$

Since $v \in \text{Ker }\pi$, it follows that $v = v\pi = 0.$ Thus

$$ \text{Im }\pi \cap \text{Ker } \pi = {0},$$
and (2.9) now shows that $V = \text{Im }\pi \oplus \text{Ker }\pi$.

b835d307-4658-4ff5-89b5-f48930afd1d3.name: Vector Spaces and Linear Transformations
b835d307-4658-4ff5-89b5-f48930afd1d3.statement: An attractive feature of representation theory is that it combines two strands of mainstream mathematics, namely group theory and linear algebra. For reference purposes, we gather results from linear algebra concerning vector spaces, linear transformations and matrices which we shall use later. Most of the material will be familiar to you if you have taken a first course on linear algebra, so we omit the proofs. An exception occurs in the last section, where we deal with projections; here we explain in detail how the results work, in case you have not come across projections before.

96db5569-453f-4f01-b7f4-787399af147a.statement: Let $V$ and $W$ be $FG$-modules and let $\vartheta : V \to W$ be an $FG$-homomorphism. Then $\text{Ker }\vartheta$ is an $FG$-submodule of $V$ and $\text{Im }\vartheta$ is an $FG$-submodule of $W$.

2fc526be-de38-4a19-8eee-a4a0760da1a5.statement:
Suppose that $V = U \oplus W$. Define $\pi : V \to V$ by 

$$ ( u + w) \pi = u \quad \text{for all } u \in U, w \in W.$$

Then $\pi$ is a projection of $V$ with $\text{Im }\pi = U$ and $\text{Ker } \pi = W$.

7d059e3a-a76e-4173-8119-c4c618c6186d.name: FG-module

759a3fb9-ad21-41c6-8fb8-8a733c283838.name: FG-submodule
759a3fb9-ad21-41c6-8fb8-8a733c283838.statement: Let $V$ be an $FG$-module. A subset $W$ of $V$ is said to be an **$FG$-submodule** of $V$ if $W$ is a subspace and $wg \in W$ for all $w \in W$ and all $g \in G$.

a82c2e34-cf0c-4251-9e30-748f099c9c6f.name: FG-homomorphism
a82c2e34-cf0c-4251-9e30-748f099c9c6f.statement:
Let $V$ and $W$ be $FG$-modules. A function $\vartheta : V \to W$ is said  to be an **$FG$-homomorphism** if $\vartheta$ is a linear transformation and

$$ (vg)\vartheta = (v\vartheta)g \quad \text{for all }v \in V, g \in G$$

In other words, if $\vartheta$ sends $v$ to $w$, then it sends $vg$ to $wg$.

8eb65c5c-6740-4424-b4cd-37303259a99c.statement:
Suppose that $V = U + W$, that $u_1, \ldots, u_r$ is a basis of $U$ and that $w_1, \ldots, w_s$ is a basis of $W$. Then the following three conditions are equivalent:

1. $V = U \oplus W$,
2. $u_1, \ldots, u_r, w_1, \ldots, w_s$ is a basis of $V$,
3. $U \cap W = \{0\}$.

proof_lines.statement:
**$2 \Longrightarrow 1$**

Since $u_1, \ldots, u_r, w_1, \ldots, w_s$ is a basis for $V$ the elements of $V$ can be written uniquely in this basis (this follows directly from the definition of linear indpendence.) But this unique representation means $V = U \oplus W$.

**$1 \Longrightarrow 3$**

If we assume $V = U \oplus W$, then by the definition of the direct sum, each element $v \in V$ can be written uniquely as $v = u + w$, with $u \in U, w \in W$. Suppose $x \in U \cap W$. Then $x \in U$ and $x \in W$, so $x = x + 0 = 0 + x$, but by the uniqueness of representation in the direct sum we must have $x = 0$, so $U \cap W = \{ 0\}$

**$3 \Longrightarrow 2$**

Assuming $U \cap W = \{ 0 \}$. We let $u_1, \dots, u_r$ be a basis of $U$, and $w_1, \ldots, w_s$ be a basis of $W$. Then $u_1, \ldots, u_r, w_1, \ldots, w_s$ spans $V$ (since $V = U + W$). We need to show that this set of vectors is linearly independent.

Suppose:

$$\sum_{i=1}^r \alpha_i u_i + \sum_{j=1}^s \beta_j w_j = 0.$$

Then then we have found a $u + w = 0$, so $u = -w \in U \cap W$. But since $U \cap W = \{ 0 \}$ so $u = w = 0$ implying that all $\alpha_i = 0$ and $\beta_i = 0$.

b02264e7-52e8-4451-b700-86ba23a79e61.name: Projection
b02264e7-52e8-4451-b700-86ba23a79e61.statement: And endomorphism $\pi$ of a vector space $V$ which satisfies $\pi^2 = \pi$ is called a **projection** of $V$.

f1ecd495-ddc9-4077-a425-67e2cf8daa4a.name: Schur's Lemma
f1ecd495-ddc9-4077-a425-67e2cf8daa4a.statement:
Let $V$ and $W$ be irreducible $\mathbb{C}G$-modules.

1. If $\vartheta: V \to W$ is a $\mathbb{C}G$-homomorphism, then either $\vartheta$ is a $\mathbb{C}G$-isomorphism or $v\vartheta = 0$ for all $v \in V$.

2. If $\vartheta: V \to V$ is a $\mathbb{C}G$-isomorphism, then $\vartheta$ is a scalar multiple of the identity endomorphism $1_V$.

6faec6ef-05b0-4010-b021-055e01ecebe0.statement: Let $V$ be a non-zero vector space over $\mathbb{C}$, and let $\vartheta$ be an endomorphism of $V$. Then $\vartheta$ has an eigenvalue.

924e371c-4b86-40b6-9fc5-93cc313fec58.name: Matrix of a group element
924e371c-4b86-40b6-9fc5-93cc313fec58.statement:
Let $V$ be an $FG$-module, and let $\mathscr{B}$ be a basis of $V$. For each $g \in G$ let 

$$[g]_\mathscr{B}$$

denote the matrix of the endomorphism $v \to vg$ of $V$, relative to the basis $\mathscr{B}$.

ca543eae-83ff-4503-9a1e-417dfb71fc78.name: FG-modules are representations
ca543eae-83ff-4503-9a1e-417dfb71fc78.statement:
1. If $\rho : G \to GL(n, F)$ is a representation of $G$ over $F$, and $V = F^n$, then $V$ becomes an $FG$-module if we define the multiplication $vg$ by $vg = v(g \rho ) \, (v \in V, g \in G).$ Moreover, there is a basis $\mathscr{B}$ of $V$ such that $g\rho = [g]_\mathscr{B}$ for all $g \in G.$

2. Assume that $V$ is an $FG$-module and let $\mathscr{B}$ be a basis of $V$. Then the function $g \to [g]_\mathscr{B} \, (g \in G)$ is a representation of $G$ over $F$.

2794d1c0-a37f-44b0-8b6d-db7af38738e6.name: Representation
2794d1c0-a37f-44b0-8b6d-db7af38738e6.statement: A **representation** of $G$ over $F$ is a homomorphism $\rho$ from $G$ to $GL(n, F)$, for some $n$. The *degree* of $\rho$ is the integer $n$.

15efadc7-f7b3-44bf-a19a-46dc3dde6c2b.name: Equivalent Representations
15efadc7-f7b3-44bf-a19a-46dc3dde6c2b.statement:
Let $\rho : G \to GL(m, F)$ and $\sigma : G \to GL(n, F)$ be representations of $G$ over $F$. We say that $\rho$ is **equivalent** to $\sigma$ if $n=m$ and there exists an invertible $n \times n$ matrix $T$ such that for all $g \in G$,

$$ g\sigma = T^{-1}(g \rho)T$$

7304c2da-a734-4097-bad6-f195a27f1472.name: Trivial Representation
7304c2da-a734-4097-bad6-f195a27f1472.statement:
The representation $\rho : G \to GL(1, F)$ which is defined by 

$$ g\rho = (1) \quad \text{for all } g \in G,$$

is called the **trivial representation** of $G$.

78c6a0f2-ff5d-448f-9522-c71b92cfae79.name: Faithful Representation
78c6a0f2-ff5d-448f-9522-c71b92cfae79.statement: A representation $\rho : G \to GL(n, F)$ is said to be **faithful** if $\text{Ker }\rho = \{1\}$; that is, if the identity element of $G$ is the only element $g$ for which $g\rho = I_n$.

fc46144c-dec4-4c38-b92c-4e9a09c77cf8.statement: A representation $\rho$ of a finite group $G$ is faithful if and only if $\text{Im }\rho$ is isomorphic to $G$.

proof_lines.statement: We know that $\text{Ker } \rho \triangleleft G$ and by Theorem 1.10, the factor group $G/\text{Ker }\rho$ is isomorphic to $\text{Im }\rho$. Therefore if $\text{Ker }\rho = \{1\}$ then $G \cong \text{Im }\rho$. Conversely if $G \cong \text{Im }\rho$ then these two groups have the same (finite) order, and so $|\text{Ker }\rho| = 1$; that is, $\rho$ is faithful.

c3ac0002-d185-49b5-9283-5429236cfda3.statement:
Assume that $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ is a basis of a vector space $V$ over $F$. Suppose that we have a multiplication $vg$ for all $v \in V$ and $g \in G$ which satisfied the following conditions for all $i$ with $1\leq i \leq n$, for all $g, h \in G$ and for all $\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n \in F$.

1) $v_i g \in V$,
2) $v_i (g h) = (v_i g) h$
3) $v_i 1 = v_i$;
4) $(\lambda_1 v_1 + \cdots + \lambda_n v_n) g = \lambda_1 (v_1 g) + \cdots + \lambda_n (v_n g)$.

Then $V$ is an $FG$-module.

82928098-1a30-4f6a-aa1d-81c2e3de0798.name: Permutation Module
82928098-1a30-4f6a-aa1d-81c2e3de0798.statement:
Let $G$ be a subgroup of $S_n$. The $FG$-module $V$ with basis $v_1, \ldots v_n$ such that

$$ v_i g = v_{ig} \quad \text{for all } i, \text{ and all } g \in G,$$

is called the **permutation module** for $G$ over $F$. We call $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ the *natural basis* of $V$.

a24f3b03-3fc9-44fd-8148-20007778126e.statement:
Suppose that $V$ is an $FG$-module with basis $\mathscr{B}$, and let $\rho$ be the representation of $G$ over $F$ defined by

$$ \rho : g \to [g]_\mathscr{B} \quad g\in G$$

(1) if $\mathscr{B}'$ is a basis of $V$, then the representation

$$\phi : g \to [g]_\mathscr{B'} \quad g \in G$$

of $G$ is equivalent to $\rho$.

(2) If $\sigma$ is a representation of $G$ which is equivalent to $\rho$, then there is a basis $\mathscr{B''}$ of $V$ such that

$$\sigma : g \to [g]_\mathscr{B''} \quad g \in G$$

927c2f1d-0f64-4301-ade6-0f4a615008db.name: Irreducible FG-modules
927c2f1d-0f64-4301-ade6-0f4a615008db.statement:
An $FG$-module $V$ is said to be **irreducible** if it is non-zero and it has no $FG$-submodules apart from $\{0\}$ and $V$.

If $V$ has an $FG$-submodule $W$ with $W$ not equal to $\{0\}$ or $V$, then $V$ is **reducible**.

Similarly, a representation is irreducible if the corresponding $FG$-module (see Theorem 4.4) is irreducible, and is otherwise reducible.

20632cd5-130e-46d8-ab36-ee546e82fd5b.name: Group Algebra
20632cd5-130e-46d8-ab36-ee546e82fd5b.statement:
Let $G$ be a finite group whose elements are $g_1, \ldots, g_n$ and let $F$ be $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{C}$. We define a vector space over $F$ with $g_1, \ldots, g_n$ as a basis, and we call this vector space $FG$. Take as the elements of $FG$ all expressions of the form

$$ \lambda_1 g_1 + \cdots + \lambda_n g_n \quad (\lambda_i \in F)$$

The rules for vector space addition and scalar multiplication in $FG$ are the natural ones.

When we add to $FG$ a multiplication operation defined by  

$$ \left( \sum_{g \in G} \lambda_g g\right)\left( \sum_{h\in G} \mu_h h\right) = \sum_{g, h \in G} \lambda_g \mu_h (gh) $$

$(\lambda_g, \mu_h \in F)$, 

we call the resulting algebra the **group algebra** of $G$ over $F$.

9ce62a80-c452-457f-bd0a-1a7c97b9a189.name: Regular Representation
9ce62a80-c452-457f-bd0a-1a7c97b9a189.statement:
Let $G$ be a finite group and $F$ be $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{C}$. The vector space $FG$ with the natural multiplication $vg$ with $v \in FG, g \in G$ is called the **regular $FG$-module**.

The representation $g \to [g]_\mathscr{B}$ obtained by taking $\mathscr{B}$ to be the natural basis of $FG$ is called the **regular representation** of $G$ over $F$.

proof_lines.statement: Suppose that $g \in G$ and $v g = v$ for all $v \in FG$. Then $1 g = 1$, so $g = 1$.

f2b1f8c3-be00-456f-a300-2eba37160bc7.name: First Isomorphism Theorem
f2b1f8c3-be00-456f-a300-2eba37160bc7.statement:
Suppose that $G$ and $H$ are groups and let $\vartheta : G \to H$ be a homomorphism. Then 

$$ G / \text{Ker }\vartheta \cong \text{Im }\vartheta .$$

An isomorphism is given by the function $\phi: G/ K \to \text{Im }\vartheta$ defined by $\phi(Kg) = g \vartheta$ for $g \in G$, where $K = \text{Ker } \vartheta$.

proof_lines.statement:
$\phi$ is **well defined**, since if $gK = g'K$ then $g^{-1}g' \in K = \text{Ker }\vartheta$, so

$$\vartheta(g^{-1}g') = e \Longrightarrow \vartheta(g)^{-1}\vartheta(g') = e \Longrightarrow \vartheta(g) = \vartheta(g')$$

$\phi$ is **injective**, since if $\phi(gK) = e \in \text{Im }\vartheta$ then $\vartheta(g) = e$. But that means $g \in K$, i.e., $gK =K$. So the kernel of $\phi$ is trivial.

$\phi$ is **surjective**. Take $\vartheta(g) \in \text{Im }\vartheta$. Then $\phi(Kg) = \vartheta(g)$.
We have shown that $\phi$ is a bijective homomorphism, i.e., an isomorphism.

1f44003e-8e2a-4f0c-9ada-dee31fb554e3.name: Vector Space
1f44003e-8e2a-4f0c-9ada-dee31fb554e3.statement:
Let $F$ be either $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{C}$. A **vector space** over $F$ is a set $V$ together with a rule for adding any two elements $u, v \in F$ to form an element $u  +v \in F$, and a rule for multiplying any element $v \in V$ by any element $\lambda \in F$ to form an element $\lambda v \in V$. The latter rule is called *scalar multiplication. Moreover, the rules must satisfy:

1. $V$ is an abelian group under addition
2. for all $u, v \in V$ and all $\lambda, \mu \in F$
    a. $\lambda (u + v) = \lambda u + \lambda v$
    b. $(\lambda + \mu)v = \lambda v + \mu v$
    c. $(\lambda \mu)v = \lambda (\mu v)$
    d. $1v = v$.

The elements of $V$ are called *vectors* and those of $F$ are called *scalars*. We write $0$ for the identity element of the abelian group $V$ under addition.

390ff1a2-1fbd-413f-a7e1-9ba7d36f3829.name: Group
390ff1a2-1fbd-413f-a7e1-9ba7d36f3829.statement:
A group consists of a set $G$ together with a rule for combining any two elements $g, h$ of $G$ to form another element of $G$, written $gh$. This rule must satisfy the following axioms

1. $(gh)k = g(hk)$ for all $g, h, k \in G$
2. There exists an element $e \in G$ such that $eg = ge = g$ for all $g \in G$.
3. For all $g \in G$ there exists an element $g^{-1} \in G$ such that $gg^{-1} = g^{-1}g = 1$.

We call $e$ the *identity* element, and $g^{-1}$ the *inverse* of $g$. Usually we write $1$ or the identity element instead of $e$.

A group $G$ is said to be *abelian* if $gh = hg$ for all $g, h \in G$. For abelian groups we typically use $+$ to denote the group operation, and call the identity element $0$.

86ea5d47-0208-47f3-b1fa-a623a97d7a54.name: Subgroup
86ea5d47-0208-47f3-b1fa-a623a97d7a54.statement:
Let $G$ be a group. A subset $H$ of $G$ is said to be a **subgroup** if $H$ is itself a group under the group operation inherited from $G$. We use the notation $H \leq G$ to indicate that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

It is easy to see that a subset $H$ of a group $G$ is a subgroup if and only iff $1 \in H$ and $hk^{-1} \in H$ whenever $h, k \in H$.

0dc0da83-97db-4a6e-b5a2-55b45a0247d1.name: Direct Product
0dc0da83-97db-4a6e-b5a2-55b45a0247d1.statement:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups, and consider

$$ G \times H = \{(g, h) : g \in G, h \in H\}. $$

Define a product operation on $G \times H$ by

$$ (g, h)(g', h') = (gg', hh')$$

for all $g, g' \in G$ and $h, h' \in H$. With this product operation, $G \times H$ is a group, called the **direct product** of $G$ and $H$.

81636cda-3d8e-44de-914d-ff3c52066a58.name: Homomorphism; Isomorphism
81636cda-3d8e-44de-914d-ff3c52066a58.statement:
Given groups $G$ and $H$, a **homomorphism** from $G$ to $H$ is a function $\vartheta : G \to H$ which satisfies $(g_1 g_2)\vartheta = (g_1 \vartheta) (g_2 \vartheta)$ for all $g_1, g_2 \in G$.

An invertible homomorphism is called an **isomorphism**. If there is an isomorphism $\vartheta$ from $G$ to $H$, then we say that $G$ and $H$ are *isomorphic* groups, and we write $G \cong H$.

53956783-7fc7-4bd1-9980-26d9ecdaf564.name: Cosets; Index of a subgroup
53956783-7fc7-4bd1-9980-26d9ecdaf564.statement:
Let $G$ be a group and let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$. For $x$ in $G$, the subset

$$ Hx = \{ hx : h \in H \}$$

is called a **right coset** of $H$ in $G$. The distinct right cosets of $H$ in $G$ form a partition of $G$ (that is, every element of $G$ is in precisely one of the cosets). 

The number of distinct right cosets of $H$ in $G$ is called the **index** of $H$ in $G$, and is written $|G:H|$.

02fee083-a2cf-4103-a52e-e16508500fc7.name: Lagrange's Theorem
02fee083-a2cf-4103-a52e-e16508500fc7.statement:
If $G$ is a finite group and $H$ is a subgroup of $G$, then $|H|$ divides $|G|$, i.e., 

$$ |G:H| = |G|/|H| $$

proof_lines.statement:
Let $Hx_1, \ldots Hx_r$ be all the distinct right cosets of $H$ in $G$. For all $i$, the function

$$ h \to hx_i \quad (h \in H)$$

is a bijection from $H$ to $Hx_i$ and so $|Hx_i| = H$. Since $G = Hx_1 \cup \cdots \cup Hx_r$, and $Hx_i \cap Hx_j$ is empty if $i \neq j$, we deduce that $|G| = r|H|$.

add5fa49-9197-4bb9-a2e5-02c10287bde0.name: Normal Subgroup; Factor Group
add5fa49-9197-4bb9-a2e5-02c10287bde0.statement:
A subgroup $N$ of $G$ is said to be a **normal** subgroup if  $g^{-1} N g = N$ for all $g \in G$. We write $N \triangleleft G$.

Suppose that $N \triangleleft G$ and let $G/N$ be the set of right cosets of $N$ in $G$. Then for all $g, h \in G$ we have

$$ \{ x y : x \in Ng, y \in Nh \} = Ngh.$$

Hence we can define a product operation on $G/N$ by

$$ (Ng)(Nh) = Ngh \quad \text{for all } g, h \in G.$$

This makes $G/N$ into a group, called the **factor group** of $G$ by $N$.

e128499c-7f9f-4e20-aed1-c0e74eefe704.name: Simple Group
e128499c-7f9f-4e20-aed1-c0e74eefe704.statement: A group $G$ is said to be **simple** if $G \neq \{1\}$ and the only normal subgroups of $G$ are $\{1\}$ and $G$.

7d27dc6f-599b-454c-a849-6cdc7c767ca4.name: Kernel; Image
7d27dc6f-599b-454c-a849-6cdc7c767ca4.statement:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups and suppose that $\vartheta : G \to H$ is a homomorphism. We define the **kernel** of $\vartheta$ by

$$ \text{Ker }\vartheta = \{g \in G : g \vartheta = 1\}. $$

Then $\text{Ker }\vartheta$ is a normal subgroup of $G$. Also, the **image** of $\vartheta$ is

$$ \text{Im }\vartheta = \{g\vartheta : g \in G\}, $$

and $\text{Im }\vartheta$ is a subgroup of $H$.

09657059-9b56-40bc-a23f-0068278c0d6b.name: linearly independent; basis
09657059-9b56-40bc-a23f-0068278c0d6b.statement:
Let $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ be vectors in a vector space $V$ over $F$. A vector $v$ is a *linear combination* of $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ if $v = \lambda_1 v_1 + \cdots + \lambda_n v_n$ for some $\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n \in F$. The vectors $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ are said to *span* $V$ if every vector in $V$ is a linear combination of $v_1, \ldots, v_n$.

We say that $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ are *linearly dependent* if $\lambda_1 v_1 + \cdots + \lambda_n v_n  =0$ for some $\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n \in F$, not all of which are zero; otherwise we say that $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ are **linearly independent**.

The vectors $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ form a **basis** of $V$ if they span $V$ and are linearly independent.

It turns out that any two bases of $V$ have the same number of vactors. The number of vectors in a basis of $V$ is called the *dimension* of $V$, and is written as $\dim V$.

2034bdd2-fffb-431f-a150-b50f5cc8d643.name: Extending to a basis
2034bdd2-fffb-431f-a150-b50f5cc8d643.statement: If $v_1, \ldots, v_k$ are linearly independent vectors in $V$, then there exist $v_{k+1}, \ldots, v_n$ in $V$ such that $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ form a basis of $V$.

e8eab3e7-94c8-4894-a4bb-4ca3115d1e4c.name: Subspace
e8eab3e7-94c8-4894-a4bb-4ca3115d1e4c.statement:
A subspace of a vector space $V$ over $F$ is a subset of $V$ which is itself a vector space under the addition and scalar multiplication inherited from $V$. For a subset $U$ of $V$ to be a subspace, it is necessary and sufficient that all the following conditions hold:

1. $0 \in U$
2. if $u, v, \in U$ then $u + v \in U$.
3. if $\lambda \in F$ and $u \in U$ then $\lambda u \in U$.

eb925e38-d0d5-4464-bbbb-caa19f7b292d.statement: Suppose that $U$ is a subspace of the vector space $V$, then $\dim U \leq \dim V$. Also, $\dim U = \dim V$ if and only if $U = V$.

proof_lines.statement: This is a direct consequence of Proposition 2.4.

5f2e2005-cd35-4819-a041-7a225f6f0310.name: Direct sums of subspaces
5f2e2005-cd35-4819-a041-7a225f6f0310.statement:
If $U_1, \ldots, U_r$ are subspaces of a vector space $V$, then their *sum* is defined by

$$ U_1 + \cdots + U_r = \{ u_1 + \cdots + u_r : u_i \in U_i \text{ for } 1 \leq i \leq r \}.$$

Note that by the conditions set out in 2.5, $U_1 + \cdots + U_r$ is a subspace of $V

We say that a sum of subspaces is a **direct sum** if every element of the sum can be written in a *unique* way as $u_1 + \cdots + u_r$ with $u_i \in U_i$ for $1 \leq i \leq r$. If the sum is direct, we write it as

$$U_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus U_r.$$

53f8e8b0-de29-4884-b44a-05a3a7eac948.name: Linear Transformation
53f8e8b0-de29-4884-b44a-05a3a7eac948.statement:
Let $V$ and $W$ be vector spaces over $F$. A **linear transformation** from $V$ to $W$ is a function $\vartheta : V \to W$ which satisfies

* $(u + v)\vartheta = u\vartheta + v\vartheta$ for all $u, v \in V$, and
* $(\lambda v)\vartheta = \lambda(v \vartheta)$ for all $\lambda \in F$ and $v \in V$.

4f775d6f-0201-4f57-84bd-83a7f6b887e7.name: Linear Kernel; Image
4f775d6f-0201-4f57-84bd-83a7f6b887e7.statement: If $\vartheta : V \to W$ is a linear transformation, then the **kernel** of $\vartheta$ is $\text{Ker }\vartheta = \{ v \in V: v\vartheta = 0\}$, and the **image** of $\vartheta$ is $\text{Im }\vartheta = \{ v\vartheta : v \in V\}.$

b75fce34-8307-410e-b822-6b140e2d1c6d.name: Rank-Nullity Theorem
b75fce34-8307-410e-b822-6b140e2d1c6d.statement: If $\vartheta : V \to W$ is a linear transformation then $\text{Ker }\vartheta$ is a subspace of $V$ and $\text{Im }\vartheta$ is a subspace of $W$, and $\dim(V) = \dim(\text{Ker }\vartheta) + \dim(\text{Im }\vartheta)$.

87b285ed-79a3-4512-b7ee-412e0576f004.name: Isomorphic vector spaces
87b285ed-79a3-4512-b7ee-412e0576f004.statement: Let $V$ and $W$ be vector spaces over $F$. A linear transformation $\vartheta$ from $V$ to $W$ is injective if and only if $\text{Ker }\vartheta = \{0\}$, and hence $\vartheta$ is invertible precisely when $\vartheta$ is surjective and $\text{Ker }\vartheta = \{ 0 \}$. If there exists an invertible linear transformation from $V$ to $W$ then $V$ and $W$ are said to be **isomorphic**.

proof_lines.statement: $1 \Longleftrightarrow 2$ is immediate from our definition of isomorphic vector spaces, while $2 \Longleftrightarrow 3$ follows from Proposition 2.7

652a9551-bad7-45f3-a13c-7471df58cda7.name: Endomorphisms
652a9551-bad7-45f3-a13c-7471df58cda7.statement:
A linear transformation from a vector space $V$ to itself is called an **endomorphism** of $V$. Suppose that $\theta$ and $\phi$ are endomorphisms of $V$ and $\lambda \in F$. We define the functions $\theta + \phi$ and $\lambda \theta$ from $V$ to $V$ by

* $v ( \theta + \phi) = v\theta + v\phi$,
* $v (\theta\phi) = (v\theta)\phi$,
* $v (\lambda\theta) = \lambda (v\theta)$.

7471da3b-ab7b-432b-879d-2a84583d9bc6.name: Matrix
7471da3b-ab7b-432b-879d-2a84583d9bc6.statement:
Let $V$ be a vector space over $F$, and let $\vartheta$ be an endomorphism of $V$. Suppose that $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ is a basis of $V$ and call it $\mathscr{B}$. Then there are scalars $a_{ij}$ in $F$ such that for all $i$,

$$v_i \vartheta = a_{i1} v_1 + \cdots + a_{in} v_n $$

The $n \times n$ matrix $(a_{ij})$ is called the **matrix of $\vartheta$ relative to the basis $\mathscr{B}$** and is denoted $[\vartheta]_\mathscr{B}$.

8d03a064-d017-4280-aee2-c76b567cabe1.statement: Matrix multiplication is an endomorphism. I.e., if $A$ is an $n \times n$ matrix over $F$ then the function $v \to vA$ where $v \in F^n$ is an endomorphism of $F^n$.

17fb05b6-a401-4ebf-8535-dea2fcf24333.name: Change of Basis Matrix
17fb05b6-a401-4ebf-8535-dea2fcf24333.statement:
Let $v_1, \ldots, v_n$ be a basis $\mathscr{B}$ of the the vector space $V$, and let $v'_1, \ldots, v'_n$ be a basis $\mathscr{B}'$ of $V$. Then for $1 \leq i \leq n$,

$$ v'_i = t_{i1}v_1 + \cdots + t_{in}v_n$$

for certain scalars $t_{ij}$. The $n \times n$ matrix $T = (t_{ij})$ is invertible, and is called the **change of basis matrix** from $\mathscr{B}$ to $\mathscr{B}'$.

18788184-b7ff-45a1-81c0-bc737a37f4bb.statement: If $\mathscr{B}$ and $\mathscr{B}'$ are bases of $V$ and $\vartheta$ is an endomorphism of $V$, then $[\vartheta]_\mathscr{B} = T^{-1} [\vartheta]_\mathscr{B} T$ where $T$ is the change of basis matrix from $\mathscr{B}$ to $\mathscr{B}'$.

dfdbdd9a-766b-428d-9b7b-8ad5b2687e15.name: Eigenvalue; Eigenvector
dfdbdd9a-766b-428d-9b7b-8ad5b2687e15.statement: A scalar $\lambda$ is said to be an **eigenvalue** of the endomorphism $\vartheta : V \to V$ if $v\vartheta = \lambda v$ for some non-zero vector $v$. Such a vector is called an **eigenvector** of $\vartheta$.

e464c8fb-c8d2-4623-ab85-9bb4e4ec6b7f.statement:
A representation of degree $n$ of a group $G$ is reducible if and only if it is equivalent to a representation of the form 

$$
\left(
\begin{array}{c|c}
X_g & 0 \\ \hline
Y_g & Z_g
\end{array} \right)
$$

where for all $g \in G$, and where $X_g$ is an $k \times k$ matrix for $ 1 \leq k < n $

131c22dc-d8e5-4e34-be50-61db26502a04.statement:
If $\rho$ is representation equivalent to $\sigma$, and $\rho$ is reducible, then $\sigma$ is also reducible.

*(Exercise 5.2 in the original text.)*

proof_lines.statement: A representation is reducible iff it is equivalent to a lower triangular block matrix representation. Therefore the result follows from transitivity of equivalence.

25b3c2ac-6261-4eea-ba4b-ad0a16c98e98.name: Action of FG on an FG-module
25b3c2ac-6261-4eea-ba4b-ad0a16c98e98.statement:
Suppose that $V$ is an $FG$-module, and that $v \in V$ and $r \in FG$. I.e., suppose that 

$$ r = \sum_{g\in G} \mu_g g \quad (\mu_g \in F).$$

Then we define

$$vr := \sum_{g \in G} \mu_g (v g).$$
